articles.headline: A Tell-All on Goldman Has Little Worth Telling
articles.snippet: After a former executive, Greg Smith, resigned from Goldman Sachs in a letter to The New York Times, he fails to deliver much more in his book on the firm.
articles.abstract: After a former executive, Greg Smith, resigned from Goldman Sachs in a letter to The New York Times, he fails to deliver much more in his book on the firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Greg Smith resigned in March as an executive director and vice president of Goldman Sachs with an Op-Ed page article in The New York Times, he leveled some sweeping charges: Goldman’s culture was “toxic and destructive”; the firm promoted “morally bankrupt people”; and — most devastating to any professional organization — Goldman Sachs bankers were “ripping their clients off.”

articles.headline: High Fashion, No Airbrushing
articles.snippet: A Web site, Rent the Runway, is offering women the opportunity to see someone their age and size in expensive clothing before renting it.
articles.abstract: A Web site, Rent the Runway, is offering women the opportunity to see someone their age and size in expensive clothing before renting it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like most women, Tina Hines has her size — an 8 — and then she has her list of clothes that actually look good on her. Side pockets are out (they make her hips look too wide). Halter tops are difficult (she needs to wear a bra). Defined waists are good, and she likes a bit of Lycra to accentuate her curves.

articles.headline: When to Call Your Elected Representatives for Help
articles.snippet: Every member of Congress has employees who do constituent service, helping people with thorny problems, often financial, that may involve a federal agency.
articles.abstract: Every member of Congress has employees who do constituent service, helping people with thorny problems, often financial, that may involve a federal agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: A common theme this campaign season has been disappointment over how little our elected representatives have accomplished of late. Gridlock and infighting have prevented the passage of much legislation that deals with long-term challenges related to tax reform, energy and immigration, among other issues.

articles.headline: Strategizing for the President, and Corporate Clients, Too
articles.snippet: Even as he has pledged to curb the influence of special interests, President Obama relies on political operatives like Anita Dunn who also represent clients who seek to influence public policy.
articles.abstract: Even as he has pledged to curb the influence of special interests, President Obama relies on political operatives like Anita Dunn who also represent clients who seek to influence public policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the rarefied world of political consultants who straddle the line between campaign adviser and corporate strategist, Anita Dunn has few peers.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: A Secretary to a Salomon Is Accused of Embezzling
articles.snippet: The secretary for William R. Salomon, the former head of Salomon Brothers, has been accused of stealing nearly $2 million from her 98-year-old boss.
articles.abstract: The secretary for William R. Salomon, the former head of Salomon Brothers, has been accused of stealing nearly $2 million from her 98-year-old boss.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 98, a venerable banker still goes to the office, even after the name of the storied investment firm he once ran has faded from Wall Street.

articles.headline: As Microsoft Shifts Its Privacy Rules, an Uproar Is Absent
articles.snippet: The difference in reactions to broader gathering and use of users’ data at Google and at Microsoft illustrates the confusion around Internet consumer privacy.
articles.abstract: The difference in reactions to broader gathering and use of users’ data at Google and at Microsoft illustrates the confusion around Internet consumer privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft instituted a policy on Friday that gives the company broad leeway over how it gathers and uses personal information from consumers of its free, Web-based products like e-mail, search and instant messaging.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Syrians Place Booby-Trapped Ammunition in Rebels’ Guns
articles.snippet: The Syrian government has salted ammunition with ordnance that explodes inside antigovernment fighters’ guns, killing or wounding them while destroying their weapons.
articles.abstract: The Syrian government has salted ammunition with ordnance that explodes inside antigovernment fighters’ guns, killing or wounding them while destroying their weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEIR SONBUL, Syria — The government of Syria, trying to contain a rapidly expanding insurgency, has resorted to one of the dirty tricks of the modern battlefield: salting ammunition supplies of antigovernment fighters with ordnance that explodes inside rebels’ weapons, often wounding and sometimes killing the fighters while destroying many of their hard-found arms.

articles.headline: Romney as a Manager: Unhurried and Socratic
articles.snippet: A serial chief executive, Mitt Romney is steeped in management theory and eschews gut instincts, wading deeply into the kind of raw data that is usually left to junior aides.
articles.abstract: A serial chief executive, Mitt Romney is steeped in management theory and eschews gut instincts, wading deeply into the kind of raw data that is usually left to junior aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As governor of Massachusetts, Mitt Romney could not resist burrowing into the bureaucratic weeds: He once took the statewide math and reading test for 10th graders, then startled his education commissioner by calling to say, “I like No. 14” and rattling off the answer.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Housecleaning, Then Dinner? Silicon Valley Perks Come Home
articles.snippet: As technology blurs the line between work and home, many companies are eschewing traditional benefits like bonuses for stress reducers like free housecleaning and dinner deliveries.
articles.abstract: As technology blurs the line between work and home, many companies are eschewing traditional benefits like bonuses for stress reducers like free housecleaning and dinner deliveries.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Phil Libin, chief executive of Evernote, turned to his wife last year and asked if she had suggestions for how the software company might improve the lives of its employees and their families. His wife, who also works at Evernote, didn’t miss a beat: housecleaning.

articles.headline: After the Boom in Natural Gas
articles.snippet: Low prices for consumers. Big profits for bankers. But the gas glut in the United States has meant much pain for gas exploration companies and their investors.
articles.abstract: Low prices for consumers. Big profits for bankers. But the gas glut in the United States has meant much pain for gas exploration companies and their investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVELYN, La.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Citi’s Torch Has Passed. Now Find a Knife.
articles.snippet: Time will tell whether Citigroup’s new chief executive will shrink the bank to a more manageable size and protect American taxpayers from future bailouts.
articles.abstract: Time will tell whether Citigroup’s new chief executive will shrink the bank to a more manageable size and protect American taxpayers from future bailouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE defenestration of Vikram S. Pandit from the corner office at Citigroup might just be a turning point for shareholders of this great big beleaguered bank. What remains to be seen, however, is whether the change will also protect American taxpayers from future bailouts.

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Say Iran Has Agreed to Nuclear Talks
articles.snippet: Direct talks would be a first, but with Iran unwilling to talk until after the election, there is a risk that the apparent breakthrough is only an effort to buy time.
articles.abstract: Direct talks would be a first, but with Iran unwilling to talk until after the election, there is a risk that the apparent breakthrough is only an effort to buy time.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Iran have agreed in principle for the first time to one-on-one negotiations over Iran’s nuclear program, according to Obama administration officials, setting the stage for what could be a last-ditch diplomatic effort to avert a military strike on Iran.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Cash Flood Fuels Fight to the End in Leaning States
articles.snippet: To earn enough electoral votes to win the election, Mitt Romney will likely have to wrest Wisconsin, Iowa or Ohio from President Obama, three Midwestern states that Mr. Obama is trying to protect.
articles.abstract: To earn enough electoral votes to win the election, Mitt Romney will likely have to wrest Wisconsin, Iowa or Ohio from President Obama, three Midwestern states that Mr. Obama is trying to protect.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — At this late stage of the presidential race, President Obama and Mitt Romney are being spared one decision that has weighed heavily on many candidates in previous campaigns: choosing which hard-to-win battleground states to abandon.

articles.headline: For President, a Complex Calculus of Race and Politics
articles.snippet: Since taking office, President Obama has attempted to balance two deeply held impulses: a belief in universal politics not based on race and an embrace of black life and its challenges.
articles.abstract: Since taking office, President Obama has attempted to balance two deeply held impulses: a belief in universal politics not based on race and an embrace of black life and its challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Obama greets African-Americans who broke barriers, he almost invariably uses the same line.

articles.headline: George McGovern Dies at 90, a Liberal Trounced but Never Silenced
articles.snippet: To the liberal Democratic faithful, Mr. McGovern remained a standard-bearer well into old age, writing and lecturing even as his name was routinely invoked by conservatives as synonymous with what they considered the failures of liberal politics.
articles.abstract: To the liberal Democratic faithful, Mr. McGovern remained a standard-bearer well into old age, writing and lecturing even as his name was routinely invoked by conservatives as synonymous with what they considered the failures of liberal politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: George McGovern, the United States senator who won the Democratic Party’s presidential nomination in 1972 as an opponent of the war in Vietnam and a champion of liberal causes, and who was then trounced by President Richard M. Nixon in the general election, died early Sunday in Sioux Falls, S.D. He was 90.

articles.headline: Disruptions: A Tiny Camera for the Stratosphere
articles.snippet: While the smartphone has pushed some camera companies off a cliff, a tiny, ultrahigh-resolution camera that can record that very feat has taken off into the stratosphere, figuratively and literally.
articles.abstract: While the smartphone has pushed some camera companies off a cliff, a tiny, ultrahigh-resolution camera that can record that very feat has taken off into the stratosphere, figuratively and literally.
articles.lead_paragraph: There have been two major milestones in narcissistic photography in the last century. The first was the invention of the self-timer, which Kodak began selling during World War I. The second came a few years ago, as teenagers stood at mirrors taking pictures of themselves with camera phones to share online.

articles.headline: Fresh Windows, but Where’s the Start Button?
articles.snippet: A radical new design of Microsoft’s flagship operating system is likely to cause some head-scratching when Windows 8 goes on sale this Friday.
articles.abstract: A radical new design of Microsoft’s flagship operating system is likely to cause some head-scratching when Windows 8 goes on sale this Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the years, Keith McCarthy has become used to a certain way of doing things on his personal computers, which, like most others on the planet, have long run on Microsoft’s Windows software.

articles.headline: NBC Finds Itself in Unfamiliar Territory: On Top
articles.snippet: NBC’s surprise top ranking among younger viewers is in large part a result of the poor performance of its network rivals, which have failed to deliver any hot new shows.
articles.abstract: NBC’s surprise top ranking among younger viewers is in large part a result of the poor performance of its network rivals, which have failed to deliver any hot new shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: The television network landscape has an upside-down look this fall: NBC, last among younger viewers for a decade, is suddenly on top.

articles.headline: Disney, Struggling to Find Its Digital Footing, Overhauls Disney.com
articles.snippet: Figuring out the Internet is critical for all media companies, but Disney’s future in particular depends on a winning strategy.
articles.abstract: Figuring out the Internet is critical for all media companies, but Disney’s future in particular depends on a winning strategy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Trying to finally master the Internet the way it has theme parks or animated films, the Walt Disney Company has redesigned its Web site, Disney.com, for the third time in five years.

articles.headline: Two Campaigns Skirt Talk of Tough Choices in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: For either President Obama or Mitt Romney, finding a satisfactory end to the war in Afghanistan and maintaining American influence in Pakistan will be a challenge.
articles.abstract: For either President Obama or Mitt Romney, finding a satisfactory end to the war in Afghanistan and maintaining American influence in Pakistan will be a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. described the Obama administration’s latest war strategy in deliberately stark terms in his debate with Representative Paul D. Ryan: “We are leaving Afghanistan in 2014, period.” Mr. Ryan did not dispute that deadline, but insisted on a little wiggle room, saying that Mitt Romney would consult with his generals about the timing and resources and conditions on the ground, to avoid imperiling America’s gains in a war that began in 2001.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: A Sale Gives a Magazine on Healthy Eating a New Lease on Life
articles.snippet: Eating Well is trying to forge its path in a world without Gourmet magazine, while avoiding high-calorie comfort food that became a popular topic during the recession.
articles.abstract: Eating Well is trying to forge its path in a world without Gourmet magazine, while avoiding high-calorie comfort food that became a popular topic during the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHELBURNE, Vt. — Employees at Eating Well magazine sometimes don’t quite believe their good fortune. Since the Meredith Corporation bought the magazine last year for $29 million, it moved out of the drafty warehouse offices it shared with curtain-climbing raccoons and a squirrel skilled at stealing bread loaves, and into a new $500,000 space with views of the Adirondacks and room to grow an edible garden. And the staff can now consult with Meredith editors at magazines like Every Day With Rachael Ray and Family Circle to brainstorm about test kitchens and effective covers.

articles.headline: Print’s Poetry Still a Draw for the Publisher Felix Dennis
articles.snippet: The magazine publisher, who took America by storm in the 1990s with Maxim, still revels in the print business and prides himself on knowing what readers want.
articles.abstract: The magazine publisher, who took America by storm in the 1990s with Maxim, still revels in the print business and prides himself on knowing what readers want.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gambling is not about luck, it’s about timing; knowing when the moment comes to grab your winnings and push away from the table.

articles.headline: BP Board Approves Rosneft Deal
articles.snippet: Under the terms of the deal, BP would remain in Russia but — initially at least — only as a minority investor in an oil company controlled by the Russian government.
articles.abstract: Under the terms of the deal, BP would remain in Russia but — initially at least — only as a minority investor in an oil company controlled by the Russian government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — BP’s board has approved an offer from the Russian state oil company, Rosneft, to buy most of BP’s business in Russia for cash and shares in Rosneft, further consolidating Russia’s control of its oil industry, an executive with knowledge of the decision said.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Benghazi and Arab Spring Rear Up in U.S. Campaign
articles.snippet: The attack in Libya last month has become the focal point of a fierce debate over what role the United States should seek to play in shaping the new order emerging from the Arab Spring.
articles.abstract: The attack in Libya last month has become the focal point of a fierce debate over what role the United States should seek to play in shaping the new order emerging from the Arab Spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — When people here talk about American politics, many look to the sky, where the buzz of surveillance drones has grown heavy since last month’s deadly assault on the United States mission in this city in eastern Libya.

articles.headline: After Benghazi Attack, Talk Lagged Behind Intelligence
articles.snippet: The gap between the official explanations and the contemporaneous field reports on the attack in Libya illustrates the difficulty of turning raw intelligence into a coherent picture fit for officials’ public statements.
articles.abstract: The gap between the official explanations and the contemporaneous field reports on the attack in Libya illustrates the difficulty of turning raw intelligence into a coherent picture fit for officials’ public statements.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Susan E. Rice took to the Sunday talk shows last month to describe the Obama administration’s assessment of the Sept. 11 attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, intelligence analysts suspected that the explanation was outdated.
